title: Part a. [0–2]
stimulusHtml:
2 points

1 point: For indicating that the magnitude of the acceleration decreases as the ball moves upward

1 point: For a correct, reasonable justification

For example: Since velocity is upward, air resistance is downward, in the same direction as gravity. The velocity will decrease, causing the force of air resistance to decrease. Therefore, the net force and thus the total acceleration both decrease.
descriptions:
The student response earns none of the following points:

2 points

1 point: For indicating that the magnitude of the acceleration decreases as the ball moves upward

1 point: For a correct, reasonable justification

For example: Since velocity is upward, air resistance is downward, in the same direction as gravity. The velocity will decrease, causing the force of air resistance to decrease. Therefore, the net force and thus the total acceleration both decrease.

The student response earns one of the following points:

2 points

1 point: For indicating that the magnitude of the acceleration decreases as the ball moves upward

1 point: For a correct, reasonable justification

For example: Since velocity is upward, air resistance is downward, in the same direction as gravity. The velocity will decrease, causing the force of air resistance to decrease. Therefore, the net force and thus the total acceleration both decrease.

The student response earns all of the following points:

2 points

1 point: For indicating that the magnitude of the acceleration decreases as the ball moves upward

1 point: For a correct, reasonable justification

For example: Since velocity is upward, air resistance is downward, in the same direction as gravity. The velocity will decrease, causing the force of air resistance to decrease. Therefore, the net force and thus the total acceleration both decrease.

title: Part c. [0–3]
stimulusHtml:
3 points

1 point: For recognizing that at terminal speed Fnet = 0

1 point: For any clear indication that the forces of air resistance and gravity are now in opposite directions, such as by showing an equation or a free-body diagram

Fnet = –Mg + kv
0 = –Mg + kvT

1 point: For a correct expression for the terminal speed
vT = Mg / k
descriptions:
The student response earns none of the following points:

3 points

1 point: For recognizing that at terminal speed Fnet = 0

1 point: For any clear indication that the forces of air resistance and gravity are now in opposite directions, such as by showing an equation or a free-body diagram

Fnet = –Mg + kv
0 = –Mg + kvT

1 point: For a correct expression for the terminal speed
vT = Mg / k

0 = –Mg + kvT

vT = Mg / k

title: Part d. [0–2]
stimulusHtml:
2 points

1 point: For indicating that it takes longer for the ball to fall

1 point: For a correct, reasonable justification

For example: The ball loses mechanical energy on the way up and on the way down. This means the average speed is greater on the way up than on the way down. Since the distance traveled is the same, the time must be longer on the way down.
descriptions:

title: Part e. [0–5]
stimulusHtml:
5 points

5 points: For an exponentially decreasing curve beginning with positive initial velocity v0 , crossing the time axis at t less than tƒ / 2, and having the final speed less than the initial speed

One point partial credit was awarded for each of the following curve characteristics.

For showing that when v = 0, the curve is differentiable (i.e., no discontinuity in slope) and has a negative slope

For showing the curve to be concave upward both for when the ball is rising and when the ball is falling

For showing time intervals for when the ball is rising and when the ball is falling that are consistent with the answer to part d.

For showing that the final velocity is negative and that the speed at tƒ is less than v0
